context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Let's say they built a lousy school, sub spec.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The roof is falling in; the plumbing leaks.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: It's a fraud, but they've given the money, the feds have given the money to the States and the States have let this slip by.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Justice Scalia's point was the Federal Government has been injured.

context.speaker: Theodore B. Olson
context.text: --The Federal Government may have been injured.

context.speaker: Theodore B. Olson
context.text: The question is what does this statute redress?

context.speaker: Theodore B. Olson
context.text: If--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: --to audit the--

context.speaker: Theodore B. Olson
context.text: --The problem is, as this Court said in the... unanimously in the Tanner case, given... forgive me for doing this, but it's important... given the immense variety of ways the Federal Government provides Federal financial assistance, always accompanied by some restrictions or conditions on its use, the inability of the substantial supervision language which the government was advancing then, which it's sort of advancing now, does not provide any test for any real guidance or--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But the Tanner case didn't confront the statute which has the definition of claims that Justice Breyer is putting to you.

context.speaker: Theodore B. Olson
context.text: --Yes--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: This statute that we're looking at, in effect, defines what a fraud against the government is.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: If it were a cost plus contract, the government would pay an extra 10,000 and it would lose.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: --That's right.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: If they... if they simply supplied defective parts, the government would get less of a machine than it paid for.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But in the... in Justice Scalia's example, the government ultimately ends up with exactly what it bargained for, and the person who's out is the person who paid for too much labor, which is general... is that your--

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: And in that circumstance, I think the scheme could fairly be characterized as one to defraud the prime contractor, because the prime contractor would bear the loss associated with the scheme.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: This statute doesn't have to cover every ill in the world.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: --That's correct.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: But fraud... fraud against the government can occur whether... the whole point of the definition of (c) is that fraud against the government can occur if Federal money is diverted away from its intended purposes, whether the deceit is practiced directly upon a Federal official or a contractor or a grantee.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: --Before... before you finish, the major objection is the one that Justice Breyer just voiced, that your position is vastly overbroad and every time there's government money there will be... one of these qui tam people can come in.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: What are the limiting principles that you say attach to this statute?

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: There are two principal limiting principles.

context.speaker: Donald B. Verrilli, Jr.
context.text: They do not inflict any pain.

context.speaker: Donald B. Verrilli, Jr.
context.text: Now, of course there are possibilities of maladministration, but not maladministration of a one drug protocol that results in any pain, and therefore there is just not a credible Eight Amendment argument.

context.speaker: Donald B. Verrilli, Jr.
context.text: It seems to me that it couldn't be cruel and unusual punishment, because there is no pain.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr. Verrilli, I think that your main argument in this case, I mean, there's... barbituate only seems to have come up rather late in the day, as Justice Alito pointed out, but your main arguments seem to be that the controls were inadequate.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: So you were beginning to say what controls would be necessary to render this procedure constitutional, and one that you said... trained personnel to monitor the flow.

context.speaker: Donald B. Verrilli, Jr.
context.text: The monitor for anesthetic.

context.speaker: Donald B. Verrilli, Jr.
context.text: And I agree, Your Honor, that it did so because it didn't believe that that was particularly relevant to the issue before it.

context.speaker: Donald B. Verrilli, Jr.
context.text: And that's the... the basis of our disagreement with respect to the legal test.

context.speaker: Donald B. Verrilli, Jr.
context.text: Now, it is... it is our position that the record is sufficiently clear and sufficiently uncontradicted on the key points with particular respect to monitoring that the Court would not have to remand but it certainly would be a reasonable thing to do in view of the deficiencies in the actual findings.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: You were interrupted, and you gave Justice Ginsburg... you said you have two problems for monitoring.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: She asked you who would do this and what measures would they use.

context.speaker: Donald B. Verrilli, Jr.
context.text: Right.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Okay.

context.speaker: Roy T. Englert, Jr.
context.text: What's deleterious about using the second drug we all agree is if the first drug is maladministered it can cause pain.

context.speaker: Roy T. Englert, Jr.
context.text: If the first drug is not maladministered no pain, no pain in humans, no pain in animals, the judgment was made weighing the costs and benefits in the veterinary context not to use the second drug, the judgment has been made by everyone who has looked at this in the death penalty context to use the second drug.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The only cost correct me if I'm wrong but the only cost that you have identified in using the one drug only are number one, the appearance cost which you equated with dignity in your response to Justice Stevens and number two, the possibility and I don't know how strong a possibility but the possibility that the one drug would not work.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Is there any other cost?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: In using one drug.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: In using one drug.

context.speaker: Roy T. Englert, Jr.
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Roy T. Englert, Jr.
context.text: The length of time it takes to die.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And I take it you don't have a figure for that, Justice Stevens said 10 minutes and I don't think you had a clear answer one way or the other as to whether there was likely to be more.

context.speaker: Roy T. Englert, Jr.
context.text: If you go outside the record of this case in which the record wasn't allowed go into the Harbison record the logic I believe Dr. Dershowitz testified he would expect it to take 30 minutes.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And 30 minutes is against some risk of excruciating pain is, that in effect is it reasonable to say 30 minutes is too long.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: So you're standard is that there has... well, don't let me misphrase it for you, but there have to be other obvious available alternatives.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: --Well, the way that we've described it, Justice Kennedy, is you that have to show a substantial risk that the method you're challenging would impose a considerably greater degree of pain than other available feasible alternatives.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: But to get into that kind of comparative inquiry, we do think that you have to get over the first threshold established by this Court's cases... that you're arguing about something other than the accidental or negligent infliction of pain, and we don't think Petitioners in this case have even gotten over that hurdle.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: So your threshold one is the only safeguard you have against Justice Scalia's concern against endless litigation, or does your threshold two do the same thing.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: Well, threshold two would as well because once you're into that kind of comparative inquiry you would still have to take a careful look at the feasible other alternative and no one has ever tried the one drug alternative.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: Justice Breyer you're right we don't know whether it's going to work in practice.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Yes but if we don't do something like that in this case Mr. Garre another case is going to come along and we are going to be right back here a year from now or 18 months from now and wouldn't it be better to get one case litigated thoroughly and get the issue decided rather than simply wait here for another one to wind its way.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: We think that this court should decide the issue.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: We think it should decide it by saying Petitioners have not established a constitutionally significant.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Sure but if we decide it on this basis the next Petitioner is going to say I'm coming into court with evidence these people did not present and therefore we are going to have a new case and new round of litigation and I think what's disturbing Justice Breyer what's disturbing me and others is we want some kind of a definitive decision here, and it seems to me that the most expeditious way of getting it if comparison analysis is appropriate and I will be candid to say I think it is is to send this case back and say okay do a comparative analysis, make the findings and we will then have a case that will in effect resolve the issue as much as one case can ever do.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: Let me make two responses to that if I could again we don't think Petitioners have shown anything close to a substantially of risk that would get you into that comparative analysis here and second a virtue in allowing there is a virtue in not going further in this case and allowing the states themselves to continue to assess this matter.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: The states have continuously reassessed and repeated modifications to their lethal injection protocols three states within the last years have taken major internal reviews of the three drug protocol California Tennessee and Florida they have all concluded that additional safeguards were warranted but that--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Court decisions have not been necessary to achieve this progress and this Court's approval of a particular method in the past has not precluded legislatures from taking steps to continue that progress.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: There is no reason I suppose, that today's decision will be any different.

context.speaker: Leonard J. Koerner
context.text: In... as this Court is well aware, the primary obligation is to find a public education for this child, and if from day one you assume that the individual education plan is defective, not only is it inconsistent with Schaffer, it's inconsistent with the whole statutory scheme which is set up to try to work cooperatively.

context.speaker: Leonard J. Koerner
context.text: Indeed--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But isn't it true that the parent will never be reimbursed?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Let's take the parent that Justice Scalia has hypothesized, will never get one penny of that tuition unless that parent carries the burden... the parent would have the burden of showing that there was no appropriate public education?

context.speaker: Leonard J. Koerner
context.text: --The parent in this case can never get reimbursed because they don't meet the predicate which is that their child had to previously--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: That's not the question I asked.

context.speaker: Leonard J. Koerner
context.text: And Congress could have concluded that the parent you're referring to who placed that child immediately in a private school, and who may not have an interest in obtaining a public school education for that child, may not be as cooperative and as collaborative as someone who has a child in the system, to work out an individual education plan because of some of these--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Then the conclusion would be that that parent hasn't met the heavy burden of showing that there is no appropriate public education.

context.speaker: Leonard J. Koerner
context.text: --But the problem is, if you go to an impartial hearing officer as in this case, and you have a child that's been in a private school for a number of years and is doing very well, and the private school special ed teacher comes in and highlights all the successes of the kid, and then the New York City Department of Education comes in with is profit plan which is based on speculation, because the child has never been in the system, is it so unreasonable for Congress to conclude as a matter of statutory, explicit language that the child should go into the system so that at least with respect to your burden there's at least a participatory program where they try to help the child get an individual education.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: If Congress's purpose really was what you... what you suggest and what I think Justice Scalia's question suggests, that there was a desire to make parents who really had no interest in the public school system give the public schools a chance, why is it that, even as you read the statute, there's no requirement that the child remain in the public school system for any significant period of time?

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: It's just pro forma.

context.speaker: Leonard J. Koerner
context.text: Indeed, Justice Alito.

context.text: But that distinction that you just made in answer to Justice Scalia could not be drawn.

context.speaker: Michael H. Gottesman

context.text: The petitioners in this case are several organizations whose members do business with the State of California.

context.text: They sued to enjoin enforcement of a California statute which among other things prohibits employers that receive state grants and state program funds from using the funds to assist, promote or deter union organization.

context.text: The Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reversed, concluding that Congress did not intend to preclude States from imposing such restrictions in the use of their own funds.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: For the reasons stated in opinion filed with the clerk, we agree with the District Court that contrary to congressional intent, the challenged provisions of the California statute regulate non-coercive employer speech about union organizing.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But I'd like you to respond to both of those things.

context.speaker: Paul M. Smith
context.text: --Well, it is certainly true that, in fact, there is no evidence in this record of any significant amount of fraud that is still occurring with the existing system of voter identification.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That wasn't... that wasn't the problem I had with your answer to that question.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: You posed a number of questions to Justice Alito, or a number of responses, but to each one of those your own answer in the brief was no, and therefore your question... the answer to Justice Alito's question should be no, there is no system that you know of that can impose a photo ID.

context.speaker: Paul M. Smith
context.text: I think... I think that the current system works just fine.

context.speaker: Paul M. Smith
context.text: So if there's any degree of burden being imposed on the voter by some additional identification requirement, then I would say it's unconstitutional.

context.speaker: Paul M. Smith
context.text: --First of all, on the point of the anecdotes, I would encourage you to look at the Brennan Center brief.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer

context.text: And my only question is, why couldn't the system make it easy for them if we really want to help America to vote, all Americans, and say we'll do it in the local precinct, somebody will be there to help you fill out the affidavit, instead of doing it in a way that's really going to discourage people from voting?

context.speaker: Paul D. Clement
context.text: And, Justice Ginsburg, I mean I see your concern, and I think if we had an as applied challenge that wasn't this kind of grab bag challenge that looks at all the various different classes of people that might be adversely affected, if we had a challenge that focused on that particular issue, I would imagine... I don't know for sure... I would imagine that the State would probably put on some evidence that says, look, there's a reason we did it that way; we piggybacked on the general provisional ballot provisions and what we decided is that, if we had people executing indigency affidavits at the polling place, it would add to the lines as the the polls.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: They didn't make that argument now.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I mean we don't have to wait until after an election to hear that, any more than we have to wait until after an election to identify the voters that Justice Ginsburg has.

context.speaker: Paul D. Clement

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The District Court rejected petitioners' arguments and granted summary judgment for the election officials.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit affirmed both the opinion of the District Court and the Seventh Circuit's opinion noted the absence of any plaintiffs who claimed that the law would deter them from voting.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: We granted certiorari because of the importance of these cases to voting laws throughout the country and we now affirm.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: In the opinion that I have authored through which is joined by the Chief Justice and Justice Kennedy, we hold that the petitioners' evidence is not sufficient to support a facial attack on the validity of Indiana's Voter ID Law.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Indiana's interest in preventing voter fraud in safeguarding public confidence in elections are legitimate and weighty and petitioners have failed to prove an excessive burden on any class of voters because petitioners advanced a broad attack on the constitutionality of the Voter ID law and seek to invalidate in its entirety, they bearing a specially heavy burden of persuasion.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: For further -- for reasons further elaborated in our opinion, they have not met that burden.

context.text: One final--

context.text: It's just, part of the deal he gave up this little ability to reopen, and that's... that's the choice he made when he accepted voluntary departure.

context.speaker: Christopher J. Meade
context.text: --One final response is that in the government's proposed regulation, an alien is permitted to file a motion to reopen notwithstanding having been granted voluntary departure, which indicates that the government itself does not think that the bargain includes... or that Congress did not intend the bargain to include a waiver of the one motion to reopen which all aliens are entitled to file.

context.text: And Justice Alito asked you: Well, then he could be removed immediately, is that not so?

context.text: Well then, that's the answer to my question.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But in your discussion with Justice Breyer you seemed to be saying that he can hang around right through the appeal.

context.speaker: Christopher J. Meade
context.text: Thank you for the correction, Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Well, is your position that the right to appeal is taken away, just as under the current regime the motion to reopen is taken away?

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: It's only the particular substantive form of relief that he requested in his motion to reopen that is at issue, and that was denied.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, that may be.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But Congress passed a statute that grants a statutory right to file a motion to reopen no matter what the relief is.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And the thing that seems strange to me, I guess to carry Justice Scalia's question one step further, is what seems strange to me is that Congress would have granted that right in effect across the board, regardless of what the reason for the reopening might be and yet would have done so knowing that the, that the time for adjudication before the IJ is likely to take longer than the period of the, prior to the moment of required departure.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: It sounds as though Congress on your view would be... would have been giving a right to reopen that in practical terms in most cases will avail the alien absolutely nothing because he'll have to get out before there can be an adjudication.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: With all respect, that's not correct.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: In this past Fiscal Year the Board on motions to reopen resolved I think only about 55 percent of those within 90 days.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: The Board has a huge backlog, and we're talking... and so we are talking about the very kind of abuse of the immigration system that this Court was concerned about--

context.text: May I ask one question?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And I'm not sure the progression in which Justice Breyer was going to begin.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I take it that the motion to reopen has... shows new evidence, new factors, new circumstances; and that would be unavailable on the appeal, because the record hasn't been supplemented.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Or am I wrong about that?

context.text: Justice Kennedy has our opinion this morning in 06-1181, Dada versus Mukasey, which will be announced by Justice Stevens.

context.speaker: Benjamin J. Butler
context.text: That's what the Federal Constitution requires.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Well, Federal rules don't have minimums and maximums.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: They have a rule.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: And as Justice Kennedy pointed out, you can have a State rule under the State constitution that goes further.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: It seems to me that the States' determination to apply Crawford retroactively must be based on a disagreement with this Court's Teague analysis, which refers back to the substantive elements of Crawford.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: So, in other words, the disagreement at bottom is a disagreement about how to read the substantive requirements of Crawford.

context.speaker: Benjamin J. Butler
context.text: But the question, Your Honor--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: But your basic position is that we should not be making new law.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: We should be... we might have misinterpreted the law over the years, but, basically, this Court has no power to change the text of the Constitution or its meaning.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I guess Justice Scalia's position is we have all that power in the world.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: My position is we have asserted all that power in the world.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Sure, as a matter of State law.

context.speaker: Benjamin J. Butler
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: But here you are arguing in favor of retro-application of Federal law.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: There is no issue... as Justice Kennedy pointed out, you can have a State confrontation clause and do whatever you want with it.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: But you are relying on the Federal provision.

context.speaker: Benjamin J. Butler
context.text: What... what we are relying on... we are relying, Mr. Chief Justice, on the substance of the Sixth Amendment, yes.

context.speaker: Benjamin J. Butler
context.text: The State court has used in the past the Linkletter balancing test.

context.speaker: Benjamin J. Butler
context.text: It's also used something akin to Teague.

context.speaker: Benjamin J. Butler
context.text: And then in this case, they held for Federal rules they have to use Teague.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Mr. Butler, if as you say Teague is, in effect, a comity rule, then what is your answer, in effect, to Justice Scalia's point that we make a decision when we come down with a substantive legal judgment about the Constitution, we make a decision as to whether the rule is retroactive or not?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And he says that if you look at Teague as simply, in effect, a comity decision, that's inconsistent with the determination that we have made, because if you say okay, we as a State will apply it earlier than the Feds say we have to, you, in effect, are changing the substantive determination that we have made, that the decision is not retroactive.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: What is the retroactivity analysis that underlies your comity analysis of Teague?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And if there is going to be some retroactivity, then I take it your position has got to be and is our substantive decisions are not so much retroactive or non-retroactive, but retroactively applied, to some extent, and not retroactively applied to others, and a State is free to apply it more retroactively than ours.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Is that the nutshell?

context.text: Second, the natural reading is consistent with the provisions placement in a subchapter entitled, Post-confirmation matters.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Justice Brandeis once observed that in most matters, it is more important that the applicable rule of law be settled than that it'd be settled right.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And to overturn a set of decisions settling one matter of the kind that Justice Brandeis was talking about, simply because we might believe that that decision is no longer right and we can get a better one now, would inevitably reflect the willingness to reconsider other matters of the same kind and that willingness could itself threaten to substitute disruption and confusion and uncertainty for what the law needs in terms of stability.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: We find nothing in this case sufficient to overcome these general considerations and for that reason, we affirm the Court of Appeals decision.

context.speaker: Christopher J. Wright
context.text: It's quite another thing if there is rampant non compliance, hiding the fact that there's been massive withholding of energy, and driving... and these spikes were not accidental, by any means.

context.text: I'm still puzzled by your answer to Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: Christopher J. Wright
context.text: --Well, I guess the ultimate distinction is that there isn't somebody making a whole lot of money on account of market manipulation somewhere.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But if they are not guilty of improper conduct in making it, then, you know, everybody has to take his lumps.

context.text: --We don't know because FERC hasn't looked at it, what... who Morgan Stanley paid and what they paid and who made the money here.

context.text: One, we that think the Justice Douglas in his concurring opinion in Hirota and the court of appeals below recognized that the theory of the Court's decision in Hirota doesn't lend itself to a citizenship exception.

context.text: The habeas statute, as this Court emphasized in the Rasul case, doesn't have a citizenship... doesn't distinguish between citizens and aliens, and it has since 1789 contained the requirement that the person be in custody under or by color of United States' authority.

context.text: So--

context.speaker: Joseph Margulies
context.text: And upon moving the Petitioners to Camp Cropper, at that moment the case becomes functionally litigable just as Hamdi would have been.

context.speaker: Joseph Margulies
context.text: That is, the government will assemble its proof to defend the detentions and present it in a district court.

context.speaker: Joseph Margulies
context.text: The only difference is that Mr. Munaf and Mr. Omar won't appear personally.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But I really wanted to get your answer to Justice Stevens's first question straight.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: You think citizenship is not relevant?

context.speaker: Joseph Margulies
context.text: Oh, no, Your Honor, I think it's extraordinarily relevant, and I think that we are entitled--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Is that the instruction that the United States gives to its officers, take care of our citizens, but the rest of the world, we don't care?

context.speaker: Joseph Margulies
context.text: Frankly, Your Honor, I do not believe the United States makes that instruction to its uniformed officers.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But you're making this distinction now.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Justice Kennedy asked you does... does your case turn on citizenship, and you said citizenship is very important.

context.speaker: Joseph Margulies
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: There are thousands of noncitizens that are being held in the very same circumstance.

context.speaker: Joseph Margulies
context.text: --No, I'm sorry, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Joseph Margulies
context.text: What I mean to suggest, the rule that I propose... the rule that I propose is that when a U.S. citizen is detained abroad by U.S. military officials who have effective authority and control over his continued detention, that citizen can invoke the jurisdiction of the United States district court.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Well, then it's not just control.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: It looks to citizenship, which brings up the questions Justice Stevens was raising.

context.speaker: Joseph Margulies
context.text: Yes, Your Honor, and I apologize.

context.speaker: Joseph Margulies
context.text: What I said at the outset is that this is a test which turns on the jurisdictional facts that I have identified, which is when a citizen is detained by the U.S. military abroad and the military has effective control.

context.speaker: Joseph Margulies
context.text: --You should definitely not assimilate this case to the latter category, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Joseph Margulies
context.text: That is not what this case is about.

context.speaker: Joseph Margulies
context.text: And let me turn then--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: In answering that question, would you go back, please, and clarify something that I'm not too clear on in your answers to comparable questions from Justice Kennedy and Justice Stevens?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And that is, you say we do not claim that there would be jurisdiction within the zone of hostilities.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Is it your point... and you then go on to say, well, they've been moved to this camp.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And is that the reason that you answered Justice Breyer's question by saying this is comparable to an occupation rather than a war zone?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Is that the simple point?

context.speaker: Joseph Margulies
context.text: --No, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Joseph Margulies
context.text: There is... there is no question that we do not challenge any right of sovereignance in Iraq to share information.

context.speaker: Joseph Margulies
context.text: The only circumstance in which it potentially arises is one in which release has the effect of being transfer and there is a prior determination by a United States district court that the transfer would be unlawful.

context.speaker: Joseph Margulies
context.text: So that--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --Well, why didn't you answer Justice Breyer... and we've interrupted you a couple of times.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: You have the box.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: He's going to be released.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: You have the box.

context.text: He's going to be released.

context.speaker: Joseph Margulies
context.text: In other words, if they just released him tomorrow... they said, we have lost interest in him; we're releasing him tomorrow... there is no prior determination that the transfer is unlawful.

context.text: Those police powers are always subject to constitutional constraints.

context.text: Your answer to Justice Souter is, Delaware can't say no more wharfs.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: So we here decide... under your view the case comes down to whether or not use of the wharf for a liquified natural gas terminal is a traditional riparian right.

context.text: Well, that's the question.

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: And the answer, Justice Souter, is not decided by the facts on the case here but rather on the individual circumstances.

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: I appreciate that there are hypotheticals that--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Then your answer to Justice Alito is, tell me more about the circumstances and I will then give you an answer.

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: --Indeed.

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: Because there are constitutional constraints.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You have said that Delaware can prevent the wharfing out and say you can't wharf out unless you get a license from us.

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: --If it is a nuisance you cannot get a license.

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: That is classic riparian law, Mr.... Justice--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, I understood your earlier answer to be exactly what Justice Scalia said.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Are you now saying that Delaware can prevent it only on the grounds of preventing a nuisance?

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: --I'm saying yes.
